entry.title: High Surf Advisory issued July 16 at 3:04AM HST until July 16 at 6:00PM HST by NWS Honolulu HI
entry.summary:
...HIGH SURF ADVISORY FOR SOUTH FACING SHORES OF ALL ISLANDS THROUGH 6 PM THIS EVENING...
.The current long period south swell (180-190 degrees) will maintain near to slightly above advisory level surf through the morning hours and into the afternoon. The swell is expected to decline below advisory levels by tonight.
* WHAT...Large breaking waves of 8 to 12 ft early this morning, declining to 7 to 10 feet this afternoon.
* WHERE...South facing shores of all islands.
* WHEN...Until 6 PM HST this evening.
* IMPACTS...Moderate. Strong breaking waves and strong currents will make swimming dangerous.

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued July 16 at 8:49AM EDT by NWS Binghamton NY
entry.summary:
The New York State Department of Environmental Conservation at Albany has issued a Air Quality Health Advisory for Ground Level Ozone until 11 PM EDT this evening.
Air quality levels in outdoor air are predicted to be greater than an air quality index value of 100 for Ground Level Ozone. The air quality index...or AQI...was created as an easy way to correlate levels of different pollutants to one scale. The higher the AQI value, the greater the health concern.
When pollution levels are elevated...the New York State Department of Health recommends that individuals consider limiting strenuous outdoor physical activity to reduce the risk of adverse health effects. People who may be especially sensitive to the effects of elevated levels of pollutants include the very young and those with pre existing respiratory problems such as asthma or heart disease. Those with symptoms should consider consulting their personal physician.
For additional information, please visit the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation website at, https://on.ny.gov/nyaqi, or call the Air Quality Hotline at 800-535-1345.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Sullivan

cap:parameter.value: AIR QUALITY ALERT IN EFFECT UNTIL 11 PM EDT THIS EVENING

entry.title: Fire Weather Watch issued July 16 at 5:31AM PDT until July 17 at 5:00PM PDT by NWS Pendleton OR
entry.summary:
...ISOLATED THUNDERSTORM CHANCES INCREASE THIS AFTERNOON, OVERNIGHT, AND WEDNESDAY...
An low pressure system will move north-northeastward into the PacNW late today through Wednesday night. This system will provide enough moisture and elevated instability for high-based showers and isolated thunderstorms to develop late this afternoon, overnight, and Wednesday.
* AFFECTED AREA...Fire Weather Zones 610 East Slopes of Central Oregon Cascades, 611 Deschutes National Forest -minus Sisters Ranger District, 639 East Slopes of the Northern Oregon Cascades and 640 Central Mountains of Oregon.
* IMPACTS...Any lightning strikes combined with hot and dry conditions could cause new fire starts.
* THUNDERSTORMS...Isolated to scattered dry thunderstorms are possible.
entry.cap:areaDesc: East Slopes of Central Oregon Cascades; Deschutes National Forest - minus Sisters Ranger District; East Slopes of the Northern Oregon Cascades; Central Mountains of Oregon

entry.title: Flood Watch issued July 16 at 3:49AM AKDT until July 18 at 1:00AM AKDT by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
Another round of heavy rainfall could lead to potential flooding for the Northern Inner Channels, including Juneau, Tuesday evening through late Wednesday night. Rivers are already starting higher and soils have become more saturated due to the most recent heavy rain event.
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is possible.
* WHERE...The following area, Central Inner Channels. This includes the city of Juneau.
* WHEN...From this evening through late Wednesday night.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, other low-lying areas and flood-prone locations. Area creeks and streams are running high and could flood with more heavy rain.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - A quick lived system will push up the eastern Gulf of Alaska and overspread a plume of moisture over the panhandle Tuesday night through Wednesday night. Additional forecast rainfall totals around 2 to 4 inches are expected within the Watch area through Wednesday night. This area has already seen 3 to 6 inches of rain over the past 72hrs with the highest amounts over the mountains, which with saturated soils, will exacerbate already swollen rivers and streams, especially within the Mendenhall Valley. Temperatures aloft will remain warm through Wednesday with freezing levels near 10000 feet, leading to increased snow and ice melt into our glacier fed rivers.
entry.cap:areaDesc: City and Borough of Juneau

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WATCH IN EFFECT FROM THIS EVENING THROUGH LATE WEDNESDAY NIGHT

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued July 16 at 3:30AM AKDT until July 16 at 10:00AM AKDT by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
Heavy rain has caused small streams to rise significantly over the past 24hrs. The rain is beginning to let up, however light rain is still being reported. River levels are beginning to lower but some are still above minor flood stage.
* WHAT...Small stream flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues.
* WHERE...Areas Around Auke Lake And Jordan Creek Mall.
* WHEN...Until 1000 AM AKDT Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas. Some low-water crossings may become impassable. River or stream flows are elevated. Soils remain saturated and excessive runoff will result in minor flooding of rivers, creeks, lakes, streams, and other low-lying areas and flood-prone locations.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 321 AM AKDT, Satellite estimates and rain gauge data indicate heavy rain across the advisory area. Between 3.0 and 8.0 inches of rain have fallen in the last 72 hours. Rainfall rates have lowered but light rain is still being reported.
- For Auke Lake near Auke Bay: At 2:00am the stage was 33.3 feet. Flood Stage is 33.0 feet.
Impacts: At 32.0 feet: This is bankful conditions along Auke Lake.
At 33.0 feet: Water from the lake will inundate yards of homes along Auke Lake.
For Jordan Creek near Juneau: At 2:00am the stage was 9.7 feet. Flood Stage is 9.7 feet. Forecast: A crest has happened, Jordan Creek river level is falling, still above bankful stage.
Impacts: At 9.2 feet: This is the stage when Jordan Creek is at bankfull and water will begin to inundate areas along the edges of the creek near Race Reality and Jordan Square.
At 9.7 feet: Water will inundate the Jordan Square's front and back parking lots, around Jordan Creek office condominiums with up to one foot of water. Some residential driveways will be flooded and cut off.
- If you live near or along Auke Lake and Jordan Creek, or other small streams stay alert and be prepared to take action.
entry.cap:areaDesc: City and Borough of Juneau

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued July 16 at 3:15AM AKDT until July 17 at 4:30AM AKDT by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
Light to moderate rain and snowmelt runoff is causing the Chilkat to rise. Rainfall has slowed but snowmelt overnight has continued the rising trend. Continued flooding is expected.
* WHAT...Flooding caused by rain and snowmelt continues.
* WHERE...The Chilkat River in areas around Mile Post 14 and 24 of the Haines Highway, near Klukwan, and the Chilkat River Bridge.
* WHEN...Until 430 AM AKDT Wednesday.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 305 AM AKDT, river gauge reports indicate rises in water levels from an area of moderate to heavy rainfall is ongoing across the advisory area. Rapid snowmelt is also occurring and will combine with rain to enhance minor flooding across the area. Between 0.25 and 1 inch of rain has fallen. Additional rainfall amounts up to 0.75 inches are possible.
- For Chilkat River at Klukwan: At 3:00am the stage was 126.6 feet. Flood Stage is 126.0 feet. Forecast: A crest around 126.8 feet is expected late Tuesday morning.
Impacts: At 126.0 feet: Bankfull stage. Water will begin to flood backyards along the Chilkat River in the village of Klukwan.
At 126.5 feet: Expect flooding of yards and bank erosion near the Jilkaat Kwan Cultural Heritage Center Campus Traditional Knowledge camp in the village of Klukwan. Water will flood lower elevations in backyards along the Chilkat River near Klukwan and start to impact some smokehouse and a river access road.
At 127.5 feet: Lower elevations in backyards along the Chilkat River in Klukwan will be underwater, and a river access road, smokehouses and storage sheds will flood. Bank erosion is expected to increase near Jilkaat Kwan Cultural Heritage Center Campus Traditional Knowledge camp. - For the Klehini River: Daily water level peaks at the 26 mile bridge gauge will occur near midnight. - inor flooding is ongoing.

entry.title: Fire Weather Watch issued July 16 at 4:10AM PDT until July 17 at 11:00PM PDT by NWS Seattle WA
entry.summary:
* AFFECTED AREA...Fire Weather Zone 658 West Slopes of the North Cascades Generally above 1500 Feet and Fire Weather Zone 659 West Slopes of the Central Cascades Generally above 1500 Feet.
* THUNDERSTORMS...Scattered thunderstorms with LAL 3.
* OUTFLOW WINDS...Gusty and erratic winds are possible in the vicinity of any thunderstorms that develop.
* IMPACTS...Scattered lightning in dry fuels can cause multiple fire starts. Thunderstorms can also bring sudden sharp wind shifts on existing fires, causing rapid changes in a fire's rate of spread and direction of spread. Thunderstorm outflow winds can be a threat for several hours following the start of a new lightning-caused fire. If a fire were to begin, air quality may diminish in the surrounding area.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued July 16 at 5:59AM EDT by NWS Charleston WV
entry.summary:
The combination of heat and humidity will lead to heat index values approaching the upper 90s this afternoon. A few locations along and south of I-64 could approach triple digit heat indices.
Use caution if planning to be outdoors. Drink plenty of fluids, stay in an air-conditioned room, stay out of the sun, and check in with relatives and neighbors.
Take extra precautions when outside. Wear lightweight and loose fitting clothing. Take action when you see symptoms of heat exhaustion and heat stroke.

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued July 16 at 5:43AM EDT by NWS Upton NY
entry.summary:
The New York State Department of Environmental Conservation has issued an Air Quality Health Advisory for the following counties:
New York, Bronx, Kings, Queens, Richmond, Westchester, Rockland, Orange, Putnam.
from 11 AM this morning to 11 PM EDT this evening.
Air quality levels in outdoor air are predicted to be greater than an Air Quality Index value of 100 for the pollutant of Ground Level Ozone. The Air Quality Index, or AQI, was created as an easy way to correlate levels of different pollutants to one scale. The higher the AQI value, the greater the health concern.
When pollution levels are elevated, the New York State Department of Health recommends that individuals consider limiting strenuous outdoor physical activity to reduce the risk of adverse health effects. People who may be especially sensitive to the effects of elevated levels of pollutants include the very young, and those with preexisting respiratory problems such as asthma or heart disease. Those with symptoms should consider consulting their personal physician.
A toll free air quality hotline has been established so New York residents can stay informed on the air quality situation. The toll free number is 1 800 5 3 5, 1 3 4 5.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Orange; Putnam; Rockland; Northern Westchester; Southern Westchester; New York (Manhattan); Bronx; Richmond (Staten Is.); Kings (Brooklyn); Northern Queens; Southern Queens

entry.title: Flood Watch issued July 16 at 3:04AM MDT until July 18 at 6:00AM MDT by NWS Albuquerque NM
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible.
* WHERE...Portions of central New Mexico from the Jemez Mountains and Sangre de Cristo Mountains including the Hermit's Peak/Calf Canyon burn scar and Las Vegas southward to the South-Central Mountains including Ruidoso, including the Rio Grande Valley from Santa Fe to Albuquerque to Socorro, the Estancia Basin, the Sandia/Manzano Mountains, and the Central and South-Central Highlands.
* WHEN...From Wednesday afternoon through late Wednesday night.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations. There is a heightened risk of flash flooding on recent burn scars, including the South Fork, Blue 2, Salt, McBride, and Hermit's Peak/Calf Canyon burn scars. Urban areas like the Albuquerque metro will also see a heightened risk of flash flooding.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - The combination of a significant uptick in moisture and increased coverage of afternoon and evening storms will result in a heightened risk of locally heavy rainfall producing flash flooding. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued July 16 at 3:29AM EDT by NWS Wilmington OH
entry.summary:
The combination of heat and humidity will lead to heat index values near 100 degrees this afternoon. Use caution if planning to be outdoors.
Drink plenty of fluids, stay in an air-conditioned room, stay out of the sun, and check in with relatives and neighbors.
Take extra precautions when outside. Wear lightweight and loose fitting clothing. Take action when you see symptoms of heat exhaustion and heat stroke.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued July 16 at 3:22AM EDT by NWS Jackson KY
entry.summary:
Heat impacts are expected today due to the combination of high temperatures in the 90s in most areas and dewpoints around 70. This will result in heat indices ranging from the upper 90s to nearly 105. The heat will be most impactful to those in heat- sensitive industries, as well as for vulnerable populations such as the elderly, young children and infants, as well as pets. Please use proper heat precautions such as drinking plenty of water and seeking shade when outdoors for prolonged periods of time.
For more heat-related impacts and an assessment of the heat risk for your area, please visit wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/heatrisk/.

entry.title: Flood Watch issued July 16 at 2:04AM CDT until July 17 at 7:00AM CDT by NWS Paducah KY
entry.summary:
Multiple rounds of showers and thunderstorms will develop tonight as a slow-moving frontal boundary moves southward into the region. Training thunderstorms along this boundary will produce very high rainfall rates, leading to a risk of flash flooding.
* WHAT...Flash flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible.
* WHERE...All of southwest Indiana and portions of southeast Missouri, southern Illinois, and northwest Kentucky.
* WHEN...From this evening through Wednesday morning.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations. Flooding may occur in poor drainage and urban areas. Low-water crossings may be flooded.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Multiple rounds of thunderstorms are forecast tonight through Wednesday morning across the Flood Watch area. Widespread rainfall amounts of 2 to 4 inches are forecast, with locally higher amount possible. High rainfall rains and saturated soils will lead to isolated to scattered areas of flash flooding.

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued July 16 at 1:27AM CDT until July 16 at 9:30AM CDT by NWS Lincoln IL
entry.summary:
FFWILX
The National Weather Service in Lincoln has issued a
* Flash Flood Warning for... North Central Mason County in central Illinois... Fulton County in west central Illinois...
* Until 930 AM CDT Tuesday.
* At 125 AM CDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain across the warned area. Between 4 and 8 inches of rain have fallen. Additional rainfall amounts of 1 to 3 inches are possible in the warned area. Local law enforcement reports that a number of roads are flooded and impassable. They also indicated that some roads are buckling. Flash flooding is ongoing.
HAZARD...Life threatening flash flooding. Thunderstorms producing flash flooding.
SOURCE...Radar.
IMPACT...Life threatening flash flooding of creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses.
* Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Canton, Havana, Lewistown, Cuba, Avon, St. David, Ipava, Table Grove, Dunfermline, Bernadotte, Smithfield, Bryant, Banner, Liverpool, Marietta, Ellisville, Topeka, Fiatt, Duncan Mills and Little America.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Fulton, IL; Mason, IL

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued July 16 at 4:02PM ChST by NWS Tiyan GU
entry.summary:
ESFGUM
A troughing pattern will be arriving from the southeast and developing over the Mariana Islands this week. Computer model guidance indicates 3 to 5 inches of rainfall can be expected on Thursday and Friday, with locally higher amounts likely. Rain showers will likely linger through Saturday into Sunday with additional rainfall accumulations.
Heavy rainfall could produce flooding of roadways and low-lying areas. People should start early to prepare for inclement weather by clearing drainages and overflow areas.
Monitor local weather forecasts and conditions closely the next few days, particularly for those planning outdoor events for the upcoming 80th Annual Liberation Day on Guam. Weather conditions will evolve in the coming days. Outdoor plans and events should have an alternate plan in place should heavy weather occur.
When thunder roars, get indoors. Tents, canopies and tarps are not safe shelter during thunderstorms. If you can hear thunder, you are at risk of a lightning strike. Plan ahead and stay informed with the latest news from your local emergency management offices and the National Weather Service (weather.gov/gum/).
TIMING: Thursday through early Saturday
RAINFALL: 3 to 5 inches of rainfall with locally higher amounts likely.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Guam; Rota; Tinian; Saipan

cap:parameter.value: HEAVY RAINFALL POSSIBLE BY THURSDAY AND FRIDAY

...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Indiana...

.Recent rainfall over the past few days following heavy rain last week has led to renewed minor flooding for a few areas on the Tippecanoe and Upper Wabash River. Those with interests along area rivers should monitor forecast updates for the latest information.

* WHERE...Tippecanoe River near Delphi.
* WHEN...Until Thursday morning.

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued July 16 at 10:49AM ChST by NWS Tiyan GU
entry.summary:
ESFGUM
A surface troughing pattern will be arriving from the southeast and developing over the Mariana Islands this week. Computer model guidance indicates 3 to 5 inches of rainfall should be expected on Thursday and Friday, with locally higher amounts likely. Rain showers will likely linger through Saturday into Sunday with additional rainfall accumulations.
Heavy rainfall could produce flooding of roadways and low-lying areas. People should start early to prepare for inclement weather by clearing drainages and overflow areas.
Stay vigilant and monitor local weather forecasts and conditions closely the next few days. Stay informed with the latest news from your local emergency management offices and the National Weather Service (weather.gov/gum/).
TIMING: Thursday through early Saturday
RAINFALL: 3 to 5 inches of rainfall with locally higher amounts likely.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Guam; Rota; Tinian; Saipan

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued July 15 at 4:17PM AKDT by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
ESFAJK
A round of moderate to heavy rain is expected for the central panhandle Tuesday night into Wednesday as a front stalls over the area. Rainfall amounts are expected to range from 1 to 4 inches in an area spanning from around Wrangell north to Juneau having the highest confidence. Some uncertainty on where the heaviest rain will set up especially to the north. This rainfall on top of already mostly saturated ground, especially near Juneau and Petersburg, may cause some river and stream rises especially in the faster reacting smaller basins.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Admiralty Island; City and Borough of Juneau; Petersburg Borough; Western Kupreanof and Kuiu Island; City and Borough of Wrangell

entry.title: Fire Weather Watch issued July 15 at 2:55PM PDT until July 17 at 11:00PM PDT by NWS Spokane WA
entry.summary:
...SCATTERED DRY THUNDERSTORMS POSSIBLE ON WEDNESDAY...
Scattered thunderstorms containing little to no rainfall will be possible over much of North Central Washington Wednesday afternoon and evening. Isolated thunderstorms are possible elsewhere across Eastern Washington and North Idaho.
The National Weather Service in Spokane has issued a Fire Weather Watch for thunderstorms, which is in effect from Wednesday afternoon through Wednesday evening.
* Affected Area: Fire Weather Zone 696 East Washington Central Cascades (Zone 696), Fire Weather Zone 697 East Portion of North Cascades National Park/Lake Chelan National Recreation Area (Zone 697), Fire Weather Zone 698 East Washington North Cascades (Zone 698), Fire Weather Zone 699 Okanogan Highlands and Kettle Mountains (Zone 699), Fire Weather Zone 702 Colville Reservation (Zone 702), Fire Weather Zone 703 Okanogan Valley (Zone 703), Fire Weather Zone 704 Methow Valley (Zone 704), Fire Weather Zone 705 Foothills of Central Washington Cascades (Zone 705) and Fire Weather Zone 706 Waterville Plateau (Zone 706).
* Thunderstorms: Scattered dry thunderstorms are possible, LAL 6.
* Outflow Winds: Gusty and erratic winds are possible in the vicinity of any thunderstorms that develop.
* Impacts: Thunderstorms containing little to no rain combined with dry fuels will lead to the potential for new fire starts that may overwhelm initial attack capabilities. Gusty winds near thunderstorms may result in rapid fire spread with any new or existing fires.
entry.cap:areaDesc: East Washington Central Cascades; East Portion of North Cascades National Park / Lake Chelan National Recreation Area; East Washington North Cascades; Okanogan Highlands & Kettle Mountains; Colville Reservation; Okanogan Valley; Methow Valley; Central Washington Cascade Foothills; Waterville Plateau

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued July 15 at 4:13PM EDT by NWS Upton NY
entry.summary:
The New York State Department of Environmental Conservation has issued an Air Quality Health Advisory for the following counties:
Until 11 PM EDT this evening, and again from 11 AM to 11 PM EDT on Tuesday.
Air quality levels in outdoor air are predicted to be greater than an Air Quality Index value of 100 for the pollutant of ground level ozone.
The New York State Department of Health recommends that individuals consider limiting strenuous outdoor physical activity to reduce the risk of adverse health effects. People who may be especially sensitive to the effects of elevated levels of pollutants include the very young, and those with preexisting respiratory problems such as asthma or heart disease. Those with symptoms should consider consulting their personal physician.
A toll free air quality hotline has been established so New York residents can stay informed on the air quality situation. The toll free number is 1 800 5 3 5, 1 3 4 5.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Rockland; Northern Westchester; Southern Westchester; New York (Manhattan); Bronx; Richmond (Staten Is.); Kings (Brooklyn); Northern Queens; Southern Queens

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued July 15 at 1:14PM MDT by NWS Boise ID
entry.summary:
* WHAT...High concentration of smoke particulates from wildfires in Oregon and northern California.
* WHERE...Baker, Harney, and Malheur Counties.
* WHEN...AIR QUALITY ALERT IN EFFECT UNTIL NOON PDT WEDNESDAY.|
* IMPACTS...Smoke can irritate the eyes, lungs and worsen some medical conditions. People most at risk to adverse health effects include infants, young children, people with heart or lung disease, older adults, and pregnant women.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Smoke levels can change rapidly depending on weather. Check current conditions on the Oregon Smoke Information Blog, DEQ's Air Quality Index, or by downloading the free OregonAIR app on your smartphone.

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued July 15 at 3:08PM EDT by NWS Albany NY
entry.summary:
The New York State Department of Environmental Conservation at Albany has issued a Air Quality Health Advisory for Ground Level Ozone from 11 AM to 11 PM EDT Tuesday.
Air quality levels in outdoor air are predicted to be greater than an air quality index value of 100 for Ground Level Ozone. The air quality index...or AQI...was created as an easy way to correlate levels of different pollutants to one scale. The higher the AQI value, the greater the health concern.
When pollution levels are elevated...the New York State Department of Health recommends that individuals consider limiting strenuous outdoor physical activity to reduce the risk of adverse health effects. People who may be especially sensitive to the effects of elevated levels of pollutants include the very young and those with pre existing respiratory problems such as asthma or heart disease. Those with symptoms should consider consulting their personal physician.
For additional information, please visit the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation website at, https://on.ny.gov/nyaqi, or call the Air Quality Hotline at 800-535- 1345.

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued July 15 at 11:47AM PDT by NWS Pendleton OR
entry.summary:
Oregon Department of Environmental Quality has issued an Air Quality Advisory...IN EFFECT UNTIL NOON PDT WEDNESDAY.
A Smoke Air Quality Advisory has been issued. Wildfires burning in the region combined with forecasted conditions will cause air quality to reach unhealthy levels.
Pollutants in smoke can cause burning eyes...runny nose...aggravate heart and lung diseases...and aggravate other serious health problems. Limit outdoor activities and keep children indoors if it is smoky. Please follow medical advice if you have a heart or lung condition.
For additional information...please visit the Web site at http://www.oregon.gov/DEQ

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued July 15 at 11:59AM MDT by NWS Riverton WY
entry.summary:
The following message is transmitted on behalf of the Wyoming Department of Environmental Quality, Air Quality Division, and the Wyoming Department of Health.
* WHAT...Air Quality Alert for Wildfire Smoke.
* WHERE...Far West Wyoming, including Lincoln County.
* WHEN...1 PM Monday until 1 PM Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Smoke from wildfires in Oregon will arrive in western Wyoming and limit visibilities at times.
HEALTH INFORMATION...The Wyoming Department of Health recommends that the elderly, young children, and individuals with respiratory problems avoid excessive physical exertion and minimize outdoor activities during this time. Wildfire smoke is made up of a variety of pollutants, including particulate matter and ozone, which can cause respiratory health effects. Although these people are most susceptible to health impacts, the Department of Health also advises that everyone should avoid prolonged exposure to poor air quality conditions.
CURRENT CONDITIONS...The Wyoming Department of Environmental Quality, Air Quality Division offers near real-time air quality data for Wyoming's monitoring stations and health effects information to help the public interpret current conditions. Current air quality conditions across the state of Wyoming can be found at http://www.wyvisnet.com/.

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued July 15 at 10:43AM PDT by NWS Spokane WA
entry.summary:
An Air Quality Alert has been issued by the following agencies:
Washington Department of Ecology
An Air Quality Alert, issued for all of Chelan County plus the Methow Valley down to Brewster in Okanogan County will remain in effect until further notice, due to expected smoke from the Pioneer Fire and other regional wildfires. Particulate matter (PM2.5) may reach Unhealthy and Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups levels.
Health Impacts and Recommended Actions: When air quality is Unhealthy, everyone should reduce exposure. Limit time outside, avoid strenuous activity, and follow tips for cleaner indoor air. When air quality is Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups, sensitive groups should take steps to reduce exposure. Limit time outside, avoid strenuous outdoor activity, and follow tips for cleaner indoor air. Everyone should watch for symptoms as a sign to reduce exposure.
Agricultural and outdoor burning restrictions are in effect.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Chelan, WA; Okanogan, WA
